description.narrative: Insatsen innebär en fortsättning av Kvinna till Kvinnas (KtK) långsiktiga arbete med kvinnoorganisationer i Georgien i syfte att stärka kvinnorörelsen i landet och därmed kvinnors röst och ökad jämställdhet. KtK arbetar både med kapacitetsutveckling av sina partner organisationer och med vidareförmedling av medel till dem. Strax över halva budgeten är avsatt för vidareförmedling av medel. Under programperioden kommer KtK att arbeta med totalt 12 organisationer varav 2 organisationer kommer att fasas ut under 2016. Tematiskt fokuserar KtK arbetet inom områdena för bekämpningen av könsrelaterat våld, kvinnors deltagande i fredsprocesserna, ökad kunskap om jämställdhet och kvinnors rättigheter och stärkt skydd för HBT-rättigheter och sexuella och reproduktiva rättigheter. Insatsen kommer att löpa över 5 år och omfattar utfasningen av KtK stöd vid programmets slut med fokus på partner organisationernas hållbarhet.

KtK support women's orgnisations in Georgia both through regranting of funds and through capacity building focusing on the area of gender based violence, peacebilding and strengthening LGBT-rights and sexual and reproductive health and rights. By strengthening it's partner organisations KtK aim to strengthen the women's movement in Georgia and thus women's voice in society.

The intended outcome of the programme is that women's organisations in Georgia, including the breakaway territory Abkhazia, are sustainable and contribute to strengthening women's participation and the respect for women's rights in the areas of gender based violence, peacebuilding and increased awareness of gender equality, women's rights, improved protection of LGBTI rights and sexual and reproductive health rights, and establishing a pluralistic civil society.

sector.narrative: Women’s rights organisations and movements, and government institutions

tag.narrative: 5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet, inklusive människohandel, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.
5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.

title.narrative: Grant Agreement between SIDA and Kvinna till Kvinna 2016
Beslut om insats - Kvinna till Kvinna 2016-2020

description.narrative: During the final year of the current program in Georgia (January - December 2020), the Kvinna till Kvinna Foundation together with its ten partner organizations (POs) continued to generate results that contributed to the foundation's fulfillment of set outcomes and objectives. The no-cost extension (January - April 2021) was mainly use to evaluate and close the program. The text below summarizes some of the main results during primarily 2020 as sorted under each outcome set: Outcome 1: Kvinna till Kvinna POs have contributed to the prevention of and protection against gender-based violence (GBV) - In cooperation with the Ministry of Internal Affairs, a PO conducted a series of trainings and awareness raising on sexual harassment, GBV and legal protection mechanisms for 425 patrol police officers and 100 police investigators. For the first time, a series of trainings were conducted for metro employees to improve law enforcers' response to cases of sexual harassment on public transport. - In 2020, there was a ruling by the European Court of Human Rights in favor of the applicant, in a strategic litigation case led by a PO on discrimination, degrading treatment and abusive police conduct. Outcome 2: Kvinna till Kvinna and POs have improved women’s contribution to and participation in peacebuilding - A PO has continued to work to represent the concerns of internally displaced women from South Ossetia to the Georgian government and regularly exchanged information with the Office for Reconciliation and Civil Equality and the Parliamentary Committee for Territorial Integrity Restoration. - Using the Gender-Responsive Early Warning Systems (GREWS) methodology, a PO wrote two reports and developed 26 recommendations out of which 18 issues were included in the agendas of three municipalities as they contained risks of developing into conflicts. Two of the recommendations were selected for inclusion on the agenda of the Ministries of Education and Health. Almost all recommendations have been addressed or resolved during 2020. Outcome 3: Kvinna till Kvinna and POs have contributed to increased awareness of gender equality and women’s rights, improved protection of LBT rights and SRHR, and a more pluralistic civil society - A PO's work in schools have contributed to more female students applying for higher education rather that getting married in an early age. The PO reported change in attitudes and behaviour as youth have started seeking opportunities and jobs that are not stereotypically male or female coded. They report on young women pursuing dreams for higher education and non-traditional jobs. This information is also confirmed by another PO. - In 2020, progress has been made towards more inclusive healthcare for trans persons which has been advocated for by a PO. The Ombudsperson issued a general proposal to the Ministry of Health and Social Affairs to establish a working group and develop state-level trans-specific medical guidelines and protocols. Outcome 4 (Cross-Cutting): Kvinna till Kvinna has contributed to POs increased organisational and institutional sustainability - During the program cycle, POs have been constantly updating risk assessment forms and mitigating risks. Especially, this relates to the COVID-19 crisis during 2020 that proved how quickly POs managed to adapt to the risks they were exposed to. Organisational assessments conducted in 2020 also demonstrated that POs security awareness has increased over the years. - In 2020, all POs received training in financial management. Seven out of ten POs also received intensive training by an audit company. All POs received training and developed Theories of Change for their organisations.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
